KOCH NITROGEN COMPANY

Wood River Terminal
East Alton, Illinois

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMP Plan)


Introduction and Policies

Koch Nitrogen Company (KNC) is committed to being associated with unmatched environmental performance as measured by its employees, customers, regulators, and the public.  KNC?s management philosophy goals are achieved by the personal commitments of employees and contractors and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the terminal, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the terminal and planned changes to improve safety at the terminal.


Stationary Source and Regulated Substance

The Wood River Terminal is one of several  facilities owned and operated by KNC along a 2,000-mile pipeline supplying anhydrous ammonia to the Midwest corn belt where it is used primarily as a fertilizer.  At the terminal, anhydrous ammonia is delivered by pipeline and stored until it is loaded on to trucks, barges, or rail for distribution.  

Anhydrous ammonia is the only toxic substance regulated under the Risk Management Program (RMP) that is present at the Wood River Terminal.  The terminal is classified as Program Level 3 under the regulation. 


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facilities are part of the high standards striven for by KNC.  These high standards are achieved by:

?Operating in compliance with all required environmental permits and regulations. 
?Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that any release will be unintentional and acknowledged as unacceptable.
?Correcting any non-compliance found during regular audits of the facility.
?Reporting promptly to r

egulators any non-compliance found during the course of audits as required by law. 
 
Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

Worst Case Release Scenario
As defined by the U. S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) RMP Regulations, the worst case release scenario is ?? the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint??.  In the case of the Wood River Terminal, this would involve a 30,000-ton refrigerated ammonia storage tank.  Using the EPA Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) methods, the distance ammonia vapors could travel in this hypothetical case would result in offsite impacts.  If such an incident occurred, an earthen dike that surrounds the storage tank would largely contain the liquid ammonia. 

Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario, characterized as a more likely scenario that could involve an offsite exposure to ammonia vapors, is the separation of a barge from the loading hose during the barge loading process.  Using the EPA OCA methods, the distance that ammonia vapors could travel in this case would result in offsite impacts. 

There are several active mitigation measures in place, which substantially reduce the chance that such an event could occur.  These active mitigation measures include KNC personnel and barge company personnel present at the barge loading cell throughout the loading operation to monitor and control the loading operations who, if needed, can immediately initiate response actions, such as activating the emergency shutdown or manually shutting off the pump.  The presence of these active mitigation measures serves to either prevent this scenario from occurring or to minimize the impact if it does occur.

These potential ammonia releases have been communicated to the terminal employees and to local emergency response officials in Madison County.


Prevention Program

The Wood River Terminal has been opera

ting under the guidelines of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program since 1992.  Ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training of employees and constant emphasis on safety have helped avoid any serious accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:

?Requiring trucks to have a brake interlock system that helps prevent a truck driver from driving away before the transfer hose is properly disconnected. 
?Ensuring no interruption in the combustion of ammonia vapors by having continuous pilots on the flare.
?Ensuring that the refrigeration system and flare operate with minimal interruptions by having a backup connection to a second power grid.
?Ensuring both instrumentation and flares operate with minimal interruptions by having a backup generator. 
?Ammonia sensors in the process areas and on the property detect ammonia and activate the Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition monitoring system if the threshold for ammonia is exceeded.
?Providing annual truck loading training to ensure driver safety. 

These safeguards as well as the vigilance of KNC?s trained employees have helped the facility operate safely since 1994.


Five Year Accident History

No incident resulting in onsite or offsite impacts from an ammonia release has occurred at the Wood River Terminal within the last five years.  Although the terminal takes pride in that record, daily emphasis is placed on the prevention and safety programs to ensure this record continues.


Emergency Response Program

The terminal will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary for the Wood River Terminal with the Wood River Fire Department, the Wood River Police Department, and t

he East Alton Police Department.  Also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Madison County Sheriff and, as appropriate, Alton Memorial Hospital, the Illinois Power Company, Illinois State Patrol, and the U.S. Coast Guard.  The Wood River Terminal Manager is responsible for coordinating all emergency actions.  A specific Emergency Response Plan for the terminal is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which the level of safety at the Wood River Terminal will continue to improve.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:

?The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures are considered.
?The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
?The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
?Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the terminal is constantly being evaluated for improvements.
?An ongoing dialogue with the Madison County Emergency Management Director or his designate will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops. 

All interested citizens or community organizations are encouraged to contact the Madison County Emergency Management Director for the latest in
formation on emergency response for the county.  The terminal plans to coordinate its response capabilities and personnel with those of the county on an ongoing basis.
